description: Odhani, or woman's veil, of black satin with very fine tie-dye design in red. Fine embroidery borders enclosing mirror chips. Embroidery.
medium: Silk, mirrors; tied resist, embroidery; dyed
text: Probably the finest embroidery in all of India came from the Kutch region of Gujarat, where minute stitching and mirror work was a specialty of several Muslim groups.  The veil here contains more than 9,000 tiny mirrors, designed to deflect the harmful intent of "the evil eye."  A wealthy Muslim woman would have worn this kind of veil and tunic only on special occasions, completing the ensemble with a pair of loosely fitting silk trousers (ejar) with embroidered cuffs.
title: Woman's veil (Odhani)
